result.name: alpine-grassland-soil-microbial-and-biogeochemical-data-from-a-climate-change-and-shrub-ex-2019
result.notes: Data comprise soil microbial and biogeochemical data collected during a climate and vegetation change experiment conducted across three valleys in Tyrol, in the Austrian Alps. Sites were located near the villages of Obergurgl (lat., long. = 46.844833, 11.023783; mean elevation = 2279m), Soelden (46.978367, 10.972217, mean elevation = 2469m) and Vent (46.863217, 10.896800, mean elevation = 2472m). Soil microbial data include phospholipid fatty acid (PLFA) analyses, and bacterial (16S Small subunit ribosomal RNA) and fungal (internal transcribed spacer region 2) high throughput sequences. Soil biogeochemical data include soil extracellular enzyme activities, soil pH, gravimetric moisture content and various C and N pools and fluxes. The experiment was funded by NERC project NE/N009452/1. Full details about this dataset can be found at https://doi.org/10.5285/977c422d-8529-432d-85d7-5de3c8dfdc5d

organization.name: eidc
organization.title: Environmental Information Data Centre
organization.description:
The Environmental Information Data Centre (EIDC) is the UK's national data centre for terrestrial and freshwater sciences.

The EIDC is one of the network of Natural Environment Research Council (NERC) data centres that provide a focal point for its scientific data and information.

The EIDC is hosted by the UK Centre for Ecology & Hydrology (UKCEH), a world-class, independent, not-for-profit research organisation focusing on land and freshwater ecosystems and their interaction with the atmosphere. UKCEH integrates UK-wide observation systems and curiosity driven research, from the smallest scale of genetic diversity to large-scale, whole-Earth systems. We work across disciplines and facilitate academic, public, private and voluntary sector partnerships. UKCEH’s extensive, long-term monitoring, analysis and modelling deliver UK and global environmental data, providing early warnings of change and management solutions for our land and freshwaters.

result.title: Alpine grassland soil microbial and biogeochemical data from a climate change and shrub expansion experiment in Tyrol, Austria, July 2019
